{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3377516,"name":"","username":"Spaceman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-30T20:55:01.145Z","cooked":"

What are the benefits and downsides of using compliant wheels for intakes and moving game pieces writhing the robot versus using solid rollers?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-04-30T20:55:01.145Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":212,"reads":340,"readers_count":339,"score":1153.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":465006,"topic_slug":"compliant-wheels-vs-solid-rollers","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60754,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/compliant-wheels-vs-solid-rollers/465006/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3377532,"name":"","username":"andej","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-30T21:20:26.017Z","cooked":"

If the thing don’t squish, you squish.

If the thing squish, you don’t squish.

(This is kind of reductionist but that’s the main idea)

Compliant wheels tend to be heavier than solid rollers on average if they are full width.

Weight, cost, friction, and durometer are all valid reasons to pick up polycarb tube. Another is durability and replaceability if its the leading edge of your robot’s intake!

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-04-30T21:25:48.977Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":296,"readers_count":295,"score":84.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":465006,"topic_slug":"compliant-wheels-vs-solid-rollers","display_username":"Bryce Hanson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31172,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"125M/7525M | MC/GA "},"post_url":"/t/compliant-wheels-vs-solid-rollers/465006/4","custom_user_title":"125M/7525M | MC/GA ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3377543,"name":"Vaughn Khouri","username":"CyberClone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-30T21:33:51.444Z","cooked":"

Compliant wheels:

Advavtages

  • Squishy, may be required depending on game piece (think 2017 gears or 2018 cubes)
  • Depending on the game piece, might grip a little better, that wasn’t the case this year though
  • Can use without 3d printing any parts (Not really relevant now that COTS rollers exist from WCP, TTB, etc, although custom printing hubs is still the way to go imo)
  • Under very specific circumstances, live axle can be easier to power (although you can make a live roller anyway so eh)

Disadvantages

  • Way way more expensive (depending on the density of wheels but to get anywhere near a roller anyway)
  • (usually the hex shaft its on) can bend if impacted or having too much force applied, which can really suck
  • Heavier than rollers
  • Forces you to use live axles, so you have to deal with the potential for bearings to pop out

Rollers

Advantages

  • Mostly already stated, but durability, grippiness since there are no gaps, etc.

Disadvantages

  • Floating silicone can be hard (but fun), cat tongue tape is expensive
  • If you glue your rollers (I prefer to) you’ll have to have full spares, not like complaint wheels where you can switch out 1 or 2 broken ones
  • You have to put some thought into designing and powering it

Tldr
Compliant wheels have been a staple in FIRST for a long time, and in my eyes that’s probably beginning to change. They’re not useless by any means - but if you are planning to have a row of compliant wheels smaller then 3 inches diameter or a shaft longer then 6 or 7 inches, I’d really start looking at making rollers.
